page.title: 14VILLAGE LIFE
page.content: The general view of Sandy Lane is that it is quite a hilly place. The hills are not sharp pointed but are rounded and have a nice slope to them. A lot of the area is used for hay and cattle. It is pasture land. There are about four farms in the area but one is now a riding stable. Most of the walls are dry uncut stone so if the wind blows it can get through the gaps without blowing the wall down. The trees grow in clumps of one and two apart from the woods at Chellow Dene. There are springs, and a beck flows down the hill. Sandy Lane is really cut into four parts by the two main roads which join at the crossroads to make the four quarters. (continued on page15)
